captions.text: We are still in Tokyo, and tonight we're going to try
one of the most typical dishes of Japanese cuisine: yakitori.
Yakitori is a type of grilled meat skewer,
usually chicken meat, although there are other types as well.
The standard version however is chicken, and it comes in many different variants.
As we mentioned already, nothing edible goes to waste in Japan.
This little diagram shows you all the different parts of chicken you can order here,
and it's pretty much the whole thing, very little wastage indeed.
Normally you'd eat yakitori with your hands, no hassle
just like any other skewer, really.
However, tonight we're dining in a fancy place
so we'll have to do it properly
work those chopsticks and that plate
Basically we'll try and pretend like we're civilized people.
And eat this stuff like a civilized person does.
In a classy restaurant.
I had to go for the odd stuff, so no surprise here
The most way out thing they had in this particular case was chicken sashimi
So tiny pieces of raw chicken meat
I'll put it on the plate, because it's rude here to eat straight out of the bowl
Anyways. It is what it is: a chunk of raw poultry
and that is jarring on so many levels.
No, that's not the right word.
It's disturbing, for me definitely more disturbing than raw horse meat
you can get horsmeat tartare in Poland on occassion, so it's less of a shock
Raw poultry, on the other hand - well, that just makes you think of diseases
Turns out in Japan poultry's raised in much better conditions
good enough to produce a chicken sashimi.
Let's give it a go
This is a truly surprising, mind-boggling flavour
because it's very delicate and very tasty
literally melts in your mouth - almost like fish
A very curious thing. But by any means, do not try this at home.
It might not be the safest thing to eat elsewhere
Raw chicken, huh. I did not expect this.
Wow, surprisingly good. I mean it.
I'm about to try one of this restaurant's specialties
It's, uh, chicken uterus.
Looks pretty gross, because of those tiny egg things
But let's not obsess over it too much
for me, this whole place and their approach to chicken is amazing
I mean, they don't just dump half of the thing like most places do
it's all being put to a good use,
and transformed into something yummy.
The trick is to eat it half and half
that is one egg per one half of the meat
This is really amazing
The yolk bursts in your mouth and pours all over the perfectly grilled meat
We just got two new yakitori
This one is chicken penis. A cock's penis that is, hens don't have those as far as I know.
And this is Achilles tendon. Chicken's Achilles tendon.

- Its weakest spot.
- Or link.
Yakitori really is one of the coolest 'must tries' of japanese food.
If you visit Japan, make sure you go to a place that specializes in yakitori
because it does shed a new light on the topic of chicken
in our culture we're quite fussy when it comes to poultry, we only eat the parts we're comfortable with,
everything that's left either lands in the rubbish bin
or is being made into some sort of unspecified mush, or jelly
Whereas here, as we've been saying again and again
it's all being used.
And on top of that, every little piece we've tried tonight
was prepared with so much love and attention
and respect to that meat
that I'm pretty sure those were the best pieces of chicken I have ever eaten
And that's the whole idea behind yakitori
you only grill tiny chunks of meat, which allows for quick cooking time
and the meat is grilled to perfection.
Plus, they only cook it to a certain temperature, I'd say medium rare
as it would be the case with beef, so they're not overly cooked.
The meat is unbelievably juicy, crispy on the outside
and at the same time it's just bursting with flavour, full of character.
To have yakitori in a decent place in Japan is a formative experience.
Yakitori is usually thought of as finger food you can grab on the go, for example when you go out.
You're having good time - you order some yakitori to nibble on.
Tonight, however, we went to a classy place that specializes in, and is well known for their yakitori
so we're making a proper dinner of it.
Usually though it's more of a snack than a full meal.
Unfortunatelly we didn't get to have anything from the rear part tonight
- turns out it's so hugely popular, they sold out within an hour of the opening.
The diaphragm. Let's try this one then.
Surprise surprise, it's delicious, just like every single thing in this place.
So yeah, this is ochazuke, a pretty popular thing in Japan
and it's what you eat after a night of heavy drinking
as you can imagine it's to prevent those killer hangovers.
We're going to add a little bit of soy sauce - it's actually homemade
so none of that cheap, supermarket stuff.
It comes with chicken sashimi as well, I think? Yeah, that's it.
It's slightly cooked obviously, floating in a bowl of hot soup.
There's rice as well, and all those funny things
Typically Japanese funny things to be specific, so pieces of nori seaweed, sesame etc.

title: Kurczak absolutny - Yakitori! [Tokyo, Japonia] / Yakitori at Toritama, Tokyo w/ English subtitles

comments.text:
+BartDab Nieprawda, to że żyjesz, w rodzinie która nie stawia na tradycje 
to nie znaczy że jada się same piersi czy schaby. U mnie rzadko się jada 
takie rzeczy. Dla mnie najsmaczniejsza jest zupa z kurzych grzebieni, oraz 
mózg. Jeśli nigdy nie próbowałeś to nie oceniaj... :d
comments.author: Boluni Kapiszon

comments.text:
Może u Ciebie. W mojej rodzinie (szrzej rozumianej, nie tylko 
mama-tata-rodzeństwo) jada się często salceson, kaszankę, tzw. "czarne" 
(główny składnik - krew), w zupach nerki, płuca, serca, szyjki itd. to 
standard. Czarnina to rzadkość, a raczej danie na specjalne okazje, 
gotowane zwykle raz do roku w dużej ilości.
Rzadkość nie rzadkość, jest to tradycyjna kuchnia polska. Zresztą w 
reportażach KG jest mowa o tym, że młodzi Japończycy nie jedzą tego, co 
jadają np. ich rodzice czy dziadkowie. U nas miałoby być inaczej? Mimo, że 
to tradycyjne potrawy, mało kto spożywa je codziennie. Takich potraw jest o 
wiele więcej.
comments.author: RaphaelAtherill

comments.text:
+RaphaelAtherill no i kiedy ostatnio jadłeś salceson ? sorry ale nie 
słyszałem o podrobach w rosole (to jakaś bzdura) a czarnina to rzecz 
zupełnie niespotykana. Oczywiście u nas również się jada podroby i różne 
elementy zwierząt ALE jest to rzadkość. 90 % osób je po prostu schab czy 
pierś z kurczaka/indyka.
comments.author: BartDab

comments.text:
Kaczą krew, czyli najwaznijeszy składnik czarniny (czerniny, różnie to 
ludzie nazywają) chyba na Wszystkich Świętych, organy wew. na przykład w 
rosole dwa tygodnie temu, a zmielone uszy i skórę znjadziesz w każdym 
pasztecie, salcesonie no i w parówkach. Z żołądka robi się flaki, a w 
jelita pakuje się np. kiełbasy.
comments.author: RaphaelAtherill

comments.text:
+RaphaelAtherill "świńskie uszy, kaczą krew, świńskie jelita, żołądek,
